responses.content:
```yaml
leads:
  - headline: Improper Input Validation in device_update.js
    analysis: |
      The fetchWithRetries function in device_update.js does not properly validate the url parameter before using it in a fetch request. This could allow an attacker to supply a malicious URL that results in a request to an unexpected domain.
      
      The doAjax function also does not validate the cmnd parameter before encoding it and using it to construct a URL. If cmnd contains special characters like & and =, it could split the query string in unintended ways and introduce additional parameters.
    cwe: CWE-20
    function_names:
      - fetchWithRetries
      - doAjax
    filenames:
      - tasmoadmin/resources/js/device_update.js
    classification: very promising

  - headline: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in a Command ('Command Injection') in device_update.js
    analysis: |
      The doAjax function in device_update.js constructs a URL using string concatenation with the cmnd parameter. However, cmnd is not properly sanitized before being used. 
      
      If cmnd contains shell metacharacters or other unexpected values, it could alter the meaning of the URL and inject additional commands when the constructed URL is interpreted by the backend. This could allow an attacker to execute arbitrary commands on the backend server.
    cwe: CWE-77
    function_names:
      - doAjax
    filenames:
      - tasmoadmin/resources/js/device_update.js 
    classification: very promising

  - headline: Inadequate Encryption Strength in device_update.js
    analysis: |
      The fetchWithRetries function in device_update.js makes HTTP requests without using encryption. URLs and data are sent in cleartext.
      
      This could allow an attacker to eavesdrop on the traffic and intercept potentially sensitive information like device IDs and commands. Use of HTTPS instead of HTTP would provide encryption of data in transit.
    cwe: CWE-326
    function_names:
      - fetchWithRetries
    filenames:
      - tasmoadmin/resources/js/device_update.js
    classification: slightly promising
```

leads.headline: Improper Input Validation in device_update.js
leads.analysis:
The fetchWithRetries function in device_update.js does not properly validate the url parameter before using it in a fetch request. This could allow an attacker to supply a malicious URL that results in a request to an unexpected domain.

The doAjax function also does not validate the cmnd parameter before encoding it and using it to construct a URL. If cmnd contains special characters like & and =, it could split the query string in unintended ways and introduce additional parameters.

leads.headline: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in a Command ('Command Injection') in device_update.js
leads.analysis:
The doAjax function in device_update.js constructs a URL using string concatenation with the cmnd parameter. However, cmnd is not properly sanitized before being used. 

If cmnd contains shell metacharacters or other unexpected values, it could alter the meaning of the URL and inject additional commands when the constructed URL is interpreted by the backend. This could allow an attacker to execute arbitrary commands on the backend server.

leads.headline: Inadequate Encryption Strength in device_update.js
leads.analysis:
The fetchWithRetries function in device_update.js makes HTTP requests without using encryption. URLs and data are sent in cleartext.

This could allow an attacker to eavesdrop on the traffic and intercept potentially sensitive information like device IDs and commands. Use of HTTPS instead of HTTP would provide encryption of data in transit.
